awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Probing Stem Cell Differentiation With Synthetic Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Deans, Tara   
Proposal Number: 1554017

The demand for stem cells is anticipated to continue to rise due to their expected ability to treat disease, use in novel diagnostic technologies, and for pharmaceutical screening. However, before these goals can be realized, a better understanding of the mechanisms regulating their fate is required. Stem cells integrate the many signals that surround them and execute cellular behaviors based on these inputs. These attributes can be harnessed and manipulated using synthetic biology to tightly control gene expression in dynamic patterns, in addition to programming cells to sense and record changes in their microenvironment.  Upon successful completion, this work will enable a better understanding of the mechanisms involved in stem cell fate decisions that may eventually be exploited to direct differentiation.

Both intrinsic (transcription factor expression), as well as extrinsic (environmental) mechanisms are thought to be involved in the regulation of stem cell self-renewal, and their commitment to differentiate into more specialized cell types. This interplay between intrinsic and extrinsic cues in differentiation poses challenges to studying the mechanisms involved in their proliferation and terminal differentiation. These challenges can be addressed using genetic circuits. The completion of this research will produce tools to query the different timings, identities, and interactions of the internal and external signals of cell fate. This will be accomplished by developing strategies for probing stem cell differentiation using genetic circuits with the following objectives: (1) to expand the genetic toolbox for dynamically controlling gene expression in mammalian cells, (2) to assess changes in the extracellular microenvironment as stem cells differentiate by connecting genetic circuits to important receptors known to be involved in cell fate choices, and (3) to use these tools to probe stem cell differentiation.  All of the results of this research will be made accessible to the research community. An additional important broad impact area of this research program is education and outreach of STEM fields at a variety of levels including elementary school, high school, and undergraduate students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes:

The research objectives in this proposal were to expand the genetic toolbox for mammalian cells to develop strategies for probing stem cell differentiation using synthetic gene circuits to provide insights to how cells make cell fate decisions. We have also dedicated some of our time to volunteer in our communities to communicate the joy of STEM fields and approaches to solve problems. Over the life-time of the award, we have made many accomplishments with both intellectual merit and broader impacts. These accomplishments are described below.

 Intellectual Merit:

In this proposal we worked on multiple aspects for building genetic tools to dynamically control gene expression in stem cells. To accomplish this, genetic parts are often taken from diverse organisms and used to establish orthogonal, independent functions within cells. Along these lines we move gene regulatory parts from a bread mold, coupled it with bacterial regulatory parts and showed that we can tightly control gene expression in mouse pluripotent stem cells (Fig. 1). These tools enabled us to look at long-term synthetic gene circuit function in mouse pluripotent stem cells and we uncovered a phenomenon called gene circuit silencing, which occurs when the cells completely silence the synthetic gene circuit, preventing it from functioning. Further work on this uncovered that we could add sodium butyrate (NaB), a known histone deacetylase inhibitor, to recover circuit function (Fig. 2).  

 We continue to be engaged in experiments to direct the differentiation of pluripotent stem cells to more mature cell fates for various tissue engineering applications (Fig. 3). We are particularly interested in driving cell fate during hematopoiesis to become megakaryocytes (MKs), the progenitor cell for platelets (Fig. 4).

Broader Impacts:

This proposal has provided broad impacts on our understanding of biological networks and gene regulation, synthetic biology capabilities, stem cell fate decisions, outreach initiatives, and scientific education. The ability to drive stem cell fate decisions without the need for expensive cytokines will improve our ability to scale up these efforts for clinical applications.

 My lab has also participated in many outreach activities over the course of the granting period. We have dedicated efforts to participating in teaching local homeschooled kids at summer camps about experimental design, execution, and drawing conclusions from their results and judged local science fairs. We also participated in Hi-GEAR (Girls Engineering Abilities Realized) summer camps for high school students, and engaging elementary school students at The Pacific Heritage Academy, a local Title 1 school in the joys of embarking on STEM journeys (Fig. 5). Altogether, we believe that outreach is an important activity to be engaged in to get improve diversity in STEM fields.


Last Modified: 10/09/2021
Modified by: Tara Deans
